required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Rubber Dam Isolation Versus Cotton Roll Isolation on Bonded Fissure Sealant Retention
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Retention of Bonded Resin Sealants Placed With Rubber Dam Versus Cotton Roll Isolation

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate and compare the clinical retention of bonded fissure sealants placed under rubber dam isolation and cotton roll isolation.

primary_outcome.measure: The US Public Health Service criteria for retention of sealants
primary_outcome.description: Alpha: No Loss of sealant, Bravo: Partial Loss of Sealant, Charlie: Total loss of sealant

secondary_outcome.measure: The US Public Health Service criteria for secondary caries on sealants
secondary_outcome.description: Alpha: Charlie: There is no clinical diagnosis of caries. Charlie: There is clinical diagnosis of caries

clinical_study.condition: Dental Caries on Pit and Fissure Surface

arm_group.description: Isolation of single tooth using rubber dam
Isolation of quadrant using cotton rolls

intervention.description: Rubber dam set is the generic name of an isolation device that consists of a rubber sheet that isolates the tooth from saliva, a clamp to hold the rubber sheet on the tooth to be isolated, and a metal frame to keep the rubber sheet in a stretched position during dental procedures.

Cotton roll is the generic name of a disposable isolation device made of cotton in a cylindrical form. Cotton rolls are used to isolate the teeth from saliva, by being placed in the cheek and tongue during placement of sealants or filings.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Teeth having a clinical indication of sealing with bonded resin pit and fissure sealants
- Patients with four fully-erupted permanent molars, with unstained, caries-free and unsealed pit and fissures
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients having incipient carious lesions, fewer erupted molars or teeth without pits on buccal/palatal surfaces.
- Patients with systemic diseases.

facility.name: LSU School of Dentistry, Department of Pediatric Dentistry
